I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Midterm Review Mission of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in 2007, the Government confirmed its 
request  for  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  preparation  of  the  Anhui  Road  Network 
Development Project.1 A fact-finding mission visited the project area in June 2008. This report is 
based on the understanding reached with the Government regarding the impact and outcome, 
methodology  and  key  activities,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements for the TA, as well as the mission’s observations. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Anhui is a landlocked province in central PRC with a land area of 139,400 square 
kilometers (km2). The province has a population of 66 million, 63% of which is rural—higher than 
the national average of 56%. The population density, at 470 persons per km2, is significantly 
higher than the national average of 138 and the central region’s 355. Anhui is one of the 
least-developed provinces, with a gross domestic product (GDP) per capita ranked 28th among 
all the provinces, ahead of only Guizhou, Gansu, and Yunnan. GDP per capita in 2006 was 
about 63% of the national average. Poverty and urban-rural disparity are the two major issues. 
Of  the  province’s  61  counties,  26  are  officially  designated  poverty  counties.  In  2006,  the 
average  annual  per  capita  disposable  income  in  the  province  was  CNY9,771  for  urban 
households, while the average annual per capita net income was only CNY2,969 for rural 
households. Of the 61 counties, 51 had a GDP per capita lower than the provincial average, and 
only 1 county reached the national average. The Government launched the New Countryside 
Initiative in 2005 in a bid to promote the development of its vast rural areas, where most of the 
poor  live.  The  accessibility  and  mobility  of  the  population  is  an  important  aspect  of  the 
socioeconomic development of the rural regions in the project area, and it must be tackled 
under the proposed project to ensure sustainable rural development. 
 
3.  Inadequate road infrastructure has been a major obstacle to economic development and 
poverty reduction in Anhui. The province had 148,320 kilometers (km) of roads at the end of 
2007. Expressways and high-standard highways (class I and class II) amounted to 2,568 km, or 
8.4%  of  the  provincial  total—lower  than  the  national  average  of  10.6%—and  class  IV  or 
unclassified roads made up more than 82%. Compared with the six surrounding provinces (see 
map), Anhui has an above-average network density (km per 100 km2), but a lower percentage 
of paved roads (as a proxy for the quality of the infrastructure). The major issues regarding the 
current  road  network are:  (i)  lower-class  road  connections  on  the eastward  corridors;  and 
(ii) poor quality of pavement, low accessibility in the south mountainous region, and weak 
resistance against disasters. 
 
4.  Developing a comprehensive transportation system under the Rising Central Region 
Strategy is a key theme of the 11th Five-Year Plan of the central Government. The strategy 
proposes to transform the six provinces in the central region—Anhui, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, 
Jiangxi, and Shanxi—into a key transport hub linking east and west, and north and south. Road 
sector development, as a way to promote economic growth and poverty reduction in the region, 
is  a  high  priority.  Anhui  Province  is  particularly  well  positioned  to  benefit  from  the  growth 
“spillover”  effects  from  neighboring  Jiangsu  Province  through  the  development  of  transport 
corridors linking the coastal growth zone with central and western PRC. 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 11 June 2008. The ensuring 
investment project is estimated to be $200 million.

2   
5.  The proposed project will support the strategy by building a 134 km expressway from 
Mingguang in the north to the Jiangsu border (toward Xuzhou). This proposed expressway will 
be part of the Xuzhou–Nanjing corridor, a high-priority corridor in the Rising Central Region 
Transport Plan (2005–2015), and a vital link in routes from the coastal area via Nanjing–Xuzhou 
and onward to Jinan (Shandong Province), Hebei, Shanxi, and the west. Traffic growth in the 
corridor is expected to be robust, with substantial proportions of heavy commercial freight vehicles 
and long-distance bus services. The project expressway, 40 km shorter than the present route 
from the Jiangsu border to Mingguang on National Highway 104, will cut the travel time by car 
from 3 hours to 2. It will benefit 2.8 million people in three counties (Linbi, Sixian, and Wuhe), 
two  of  which  (Linbi  and  Sixian)  are  officially  designated  poverty  counties,  and  one  city 
(Mingguang). 
 
6.  The Anhui Provincial Communications Investment Group Company (ACIG) was set up 
by the government in May 2001 to develop and operate higways in Anhui. It will build and 
operate the proposed expressway, and is actively seeking private sector participation. Although 
the proposed expressway is being planned in the public sector, various options for involving the 
private  sector  in  its  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  (through  non-sovereign  loan 
financing, outsourcing, or the sale of operating rights, among others) will be explored under the 
TA, with the aim of evaluating and setting new standards for corporate governance. 
 
7.  To improve services and connections on the overall road network, the Anhui Provincial 
Communications Department (APCD) plans to improve about 5,700 km of national and provincial 
roads. Part of the proposed project will be the rehabilitation and upgrading of 10 sections of the 
local road network totaling 552 km (see map). These comprise three sections in northeastern 
Anhui that are directly related to the proposed expressway; three in the poor and mountainous 
southwestern  quadrant  of  the  province;  two  sections  of  key  roads  leading  south  to  Jiangxi 
Province; a key connector east to Yangzhou City in Jiangsu Province; and a strategic local link 
between Hefei and the neighboring city of Chaohu. The road upgrading will improve (i) the sharing 
of benefits from the expressway and nonfarm development potential in the northeast of the 
province,  (ii) road  safety  and  environment  in  the  mountainous  region,  (iii) integration  with 
neighboring provinces, and (iv) the rural population’s access to outside markets. 
 
8.  Road  safety  standards  throughout  the  PRC  are  recognized  to  be  poor,  with 
unacceptably high accident and fatality rates. In 2007, there were 9,240 road accidents in Anhui, 
resulting in almost 3,000 deaths and more than 12,000 injuries. The poor road conditions increase 
the risk and severity of accidents. During the TA Fact-Finding Mission, ADB and APCD agreed to 
develop and implement a focused program of accident countermeasures, initially on the project 
roads but later throughout the province. Specific attention will be paid to urban sections, where 
through  traffic  and  local  needs  vie  for  access,  and  to  mountain  sections  with  substandard 
alignments. These measures will be accompanied by a targeted program of enforcement and 
publicity. A study under the TA will assist in identifying and evaluating the requirements of the 
proposed road safety enhancement program to be financed under the ensuing ADB loan. 
 
9.  Despite good progress in providing rural transport services connecting townships with 
counties,  some  3,800  administrative  villages  still  have  no  formal  bus  services.  Transport 
demand  is  usually  met  by  various  informal  transport  services.  Under  the  Promote  Rural 
Transport Service Plan of APCD for organized bus services to rural areas, 1,100 township bus 
stations will be built in the province. The proposed project will support the construction of 
50 class V  or class VI  township  bus  stations,  mostly  by  improving  the  existing  township 
transport management stations. The upgraded bus stations will (i) conform to the APCD plan, 
(ii) contribute to an integrated solution to the need for accessibility, (iii) help improve access to

3 
poorer villages and townships in the province, and (iv) serve as a focus for bus services 
between  townships  and  surrounding  villages.  Combining  the  bus  and  township  transport 
management  stations  will  afford  greater  convenience  for  passengers  and  minimize  land 
acquisition. 
 
10.  APCD will implement a system of regional route licensing to give bus operators more 
flexibility in customizing bus routes, schedules, and services to suit passenger needs, and allow 
them to use their vehicles and drivers more efficiently. The licensing system, to be implemented 
between townships and nearby villages in three pilot counties, to start with, is expected to 
increase productivity and lower unit costs. Ultimately, the lower costs should lead to lower fares 
and better service. A study under the TA will assist with the implementation of the proposed rural 
transport reform demonstration project. Experience from the demonstration project will be used in 
replicating the reform in other areas of the province. 
 
11.  The proposed project is consistent with the 11th Five-Year Plan and ADB’s country 
partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC,  which  is  concerned  with  managing  the  environment, 
catalyzing investment, and improving knowledge products, among others.2 It conforms to ADB’s 
road sector assistance strategy in PRC. The strategy aims to provide financing and policy 
advice in the PRC to (i) support the construction of roads that connect major growth centers, 
together with the subsidiary local roads; (ii) develop and improve urban transport and rural 
roads; (iii) promote road safety, cut vehicle emissions, and raise energy efficiency; (iv) improve 
the commercial orientation and efficiency of expressway organizations; (v) strengthen regional 
cooperation in transport; (vi) promote public–private partnership; and (vii) establish resource 
efficient transport. ADB road sector assistance targets the less-developed central and western 
provinces, where most of the poor live. Recent reviews of the transport sector assistance 
program3 concluded that ADB’s support for the PRC road sector in 1997–2005 was a success, 
but suggested giving more attention to value addition in ADB-financed road projects. That 
recommendation will be taken into account in the preparation of the proposed project. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The proposed project will improve the road transport network in Anhui Province and 
make it more efficient, safe, and environment-friendly. The outcome of the TA will be an agreed 
project design and implementation arrangements suitable for ADB financing. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Three subprojects namely (i) the expressway construction, (ii) local road rehabilitation 
including  traffic  safety  improvement,  and  (iii)  the  rural  transport  services  improvement 
demonstration will be prepared under the TA. The consultants will (i) review the economic and 
environmental development strategies, priorities, and investment plan; (ii) identify the problems 
relating to road infrastructure; services, environment, and safety issues and the urgency of 
mitigating the identified needs; (iii) assess the potential impact of the subprojects on the basis of 
technical, institutional, environmental, social, economic, financial, and other relevant factors;

(iv) formulate balanced road network development and management strategies with measures 
to strengthen local road safety and promote environmental protection while improving rural 
transport  services;  (v)  review  and  update  the relevant  studies,  analyses,  and  data  on  the 
feasibility of the three subprojects; (vi) assist the APCD in preparing and strengthening the 
environmental impact assessments, resettlement plans, and social development action plan 
according  to  ADB’s  policies  and  guidelines,  and  in  conducting  public  consultations  and 
disclosing relevant information; (vii) develop a project design and monitoring framework and 
refine  it  through  a  stakeholder  workshop;  and  (viii) prepare  a  project  loan  proposal  for 
consideration  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  The  initial  poverty  and  social  analysis  is  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The consultants will prepare short best-practices or policy notes linked to the following 
areas, where high-level policy dialogue with key decision makers is envisaged: (i) local road 
development strategy, (ii) local road maintenance financing and prioritization, (iii) local road 
safety, (iv) rural transport services, (v) axle load enforcement, (vi) vehicle emission reduction, 
(vii) private sector financing, (viii) institutional development road map and action plans for ACIG, 
and (ix) capacity-building program for APCD. 
 
15.  Major risks to the successful implementation of the TA are: (i) inadequate counterpart 
support and performance, (ii) inadequate or unavailable data, (iii) delayed submission of the 
required studies, (iv) delayed recruitment and mobilization of consultants and design institutes, 
and (v) inadequate performance of the consultants and design institutes. To mitigate these risks, 
the recruitment and performance of the consultants and design institutes will be monitored 
closely. The Government has also agreed to provide adequate counterpart support and all the 
necessary data according to an agreed timetable. Close coordination among the consultants, 
the executing and implementing agencies, and ADB will further reduce the risks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000. At the request of the Government, 
ADB will finance $600,000 of that amount with a grant from its TA funding program. The 
Government will finance the rest of the local currency cost, equivalent to $150,000, by providing 
counterpart  staff,  office  facilities,  and  other  support  services.  The  Government  has  been 
informed that the approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The 
 
detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3.
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  APCD will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The implementing agencies (IAs) will be 
ACIG for the expressway construction, the Anhui Highway Administration Bureau for the local 
road  rehabilitation  and  traffic  safety  improvement  on  local  road  network,  and  the  Anhui 
Transport  Administration  Bureau  (ATAB)  for  the  rural  transport  services  improvement 
demonstration. APCD has set up a project management office (PMO) to give overall guidance 
and support to the proposed project.4 The PMO will ensure the study team has access to 
relevant information and data, coordinate with ADB and related departments and bureaus in 
APCD in TA implementation, and facilitate the required socioeconomic, poverty, and other 
surveys. The PMO is led by a director and has at least three experienced professional staff, 
including a translator, who will work full-time with the consultants. 
 
                                                 
4  The PMO was established in APCD in 1997 to implement World Bank–financed projects.

5 
18.  The TA will have three parts, to be implemented over 10 months, from December 2008 
to September 2009. Part A will involve the overall project preparation and best-practices or 
policy  notes  preparation  (see  para.  2  of  appendix  4).  It  will  require  21  person-months  of 
consulting services (8 international and 13 national). The international consultants will provide 
expertise  in  (i) highway  engineering  and  road  safety,  (ii) transport  economics,  (iii)  financial 
analysis and private sector development, and (iv) transport services. The national consultants 
will  have  expertise  in  (i)  highway  engineering,  (ii) economic  and  financial  analysis, 
(iii) environmental impact assessment, (iv) resettlement planning, and (v) social (poverty and 
gender) impact analysis. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  A consulting firm will be hired for part A according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). ADB will select and hire the consultants 
through simplified technical proposal procedures according to the quality of their technical 
proposal (90%) and the cost (10%) of the services to be provided (quality- and cost-based 
selection). The 90:10 weighting is considered appropriate because the proposed project is a 
complex, multidisciplinary assignment that requires innovation and creativity, and the quality of 
the consulting services will have a high impact on the ensuing loan. The consultants will prepare 
all their reports in English and Chinese, and will maintain close working relations and discuss 
progress and findings with ADB, the PMO, and the three IAs. Tripartite meetings among ADB 
staff, the consultants, the PMO, and the three IAs will be held in Hefei, to guide the consultants 
and to review their reports. 
 
20.  Part B will be concerned with local road rehabilitation and traffic safety improvement on 
local road network, and part C with the preparation of a rural transport services improvement 
demonstration project in Anhui as recommended by the Sustainable Rural Transport Services 
TA.5 Parts B and C will each require 12 person-months of consulting services to be undertaken 
by national consulting firms. Given the very small value of the contracts and the intensive 
relevant experience of the two national firms6 recommended by APCD for the studies, ADB will 
hire  the  firms  through  single-source  selection  according  to  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants. The two teams will work closely with the study team for part A. The terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
21.  APCD will provide a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access; 
city transport for the consultants; materials, maps, data, and documents required for the TA; and 
the cost of utilities for the use of the consultants, counterpart professional staff, and support staff. 
The  TA  equipment  will  be  procured  by  the  consultants  according  to  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and transferred to APCD after the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Anhui Road Network 
Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy and the sector analysis describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy 
of the partner country. 
  A key part of the Government’s 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010) is the Rising Central Region Strategy, whose aim 
is to develop the six poor provinces in the central region of the PRC (Anhui, Henan, Hubei, and Hunan, Jiangxi, and 
Shanxi). Of the six, Anhui is the least developed. However, it has locational advantages, in particular, its proximity to 
the dynamic development pole around the Yangtze River Delta. Underdeveloped roads and the associated high 
transportation costs are major barriers to the reduction of poverty in Anhui. Better roads would contribute directly to 
poverty reduction by improving access to markets, employment opportunities, and social services, and indirectly by 
stimulating economic development. 
  The proposed expressway is in northeastern Anhui, where the major agricultural products are wheat, corn, animal 
husbandry  products,  peanut,  soybean,  and  vegetables.  National  Highway  104  (classes II–III)  provides  good 
transport access to the region, but its capacity is limited. Further, the local road network is poorly developed because 
of slow economic development. The proposed project will comprise the construction of an expressway and the 
improvement of local roads and transport services, to promote and facilitate the social and economic development of 
the region. 
 
B.   Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 General Intervention (GI)   Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs 
  (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
The proposed project will contribute indirectly to poverty reduction in the project area by generating economic and 
employment opportunities through improved access to the Yangtze River Delta, the most vibrant development area in the 
PRC. It will substantially improve transport infrastructure and services and will facilitate economic development, thus 
providing more employment and income opportunities for local people. The proposed project will also improve access to 
social services in the county centers and towns. 
 
Anhui is the fourth-poorest province in the country, in terms of GDP per capita (63% of the national average in 2006). Of 
the 61 counties in the province, 18 were officially designated national poor counties in 2006, and 8, provincial poor 
counties. In 2006, the average annual disposable income was CNY9,771 for urban residents, but only CNY2,969 for rural 
residents. The proposed main road (expressway) will affect the four counties of Anhui—Mingguang City in Chuzhou, 
Wuhe County in Bengbu, and Lingbi and Sixian counties in Suzhou. These four counties are less developed than the 
provincial average. In 2006, GDP per capita in these counties was CNY4,652 in Lingbi, CNY 5,640 in Sixian, CNY7,335 
in Wuhe, and CNY6,277 in Mingguang. Lingbi and Sixian Counties are provincially designated poor counties. In 2006, the 
rural net income per capita was CNY2,367 in Lingbi and CNY2,520 in Sixian County, compared with the provincial 
average of CNY2,969. The incidence of rural poor (net income below the average level) was 55.2% in Minguang, 41.7% 
in Wuhe, 74.0% in Lingbi, and 52.6% in Sixian County.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
  Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from 
the project? 
 
The primary beneficiaries of the proposed project will be the people and businesses in cities, towns, and villages along 
the project roads. With more convenient transport, agricultural products can reach market at lower cost, high-value cash 
crops will replace common agricultural products, investments from the Yangtze River Delta will come into the project 
area, and employment opportunities will increase greatly.  
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
People in the project area now suffer from poor transport, which makes it difficult for them to benefit from the economic 
developments  on  the  east  coast.  They  look  forward  to  the  improved  market  and  employment  opportunities  in 
nonagricultural occupations that the proposed project will bring about. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? 
 
The main potential constraint is the poor condition of local roads. Hence, the improvement of the local road network will 
be given great importance in the proposed project. During the TA, the possibility of providing a drying yard for peasants 
while local roads are being rebuilt and upgraded will also be studied. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation

and local residents.

community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)? 
 
Consultations began during the preparation of the preliminary feasibility study, which looked into three major alternatives

A.   Impact and Output 
1.  The project impact will be an improved, efficient, safe, and environment-friendly road 
transport network in Anhui Province. The technical assistance (TA) outcome will be to produce 
an agreed project design and implementation arrangements suitable for Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) financing.  
B.  Overall Scope of Work 
 
2.  Policy Dialogue-Related Activities. Policy dialogue is ongoing between ADB and the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) in connection with ADB’s transport lending program in the 
PRC. To strengthen the dialogue in relation to the project, the consultants will prepare short 
best  practices  and/or  notes  for  policy  dialogue―based  on  discussions  with  the  provincial 
government―on: (i) local road development strategy, (ii) local road maintenance financing and 
prioritization, (iii) local road safety, (iv) rural transport services, (v) axle load enforcement, 
(vi) reduction of vehicle emissions, (vii) private sector financing, (viii) institutional development 
road map and action plans for Anhui Provincial Communications Investment Group Company 
(ACIG), and (ix) capacity building program for Anhui Provincial Communications Department. 
 
3.  Design and Monitoring Framework. The consultants will develop, through stakeholder 
workshops  and  meetings,  a  design  and  monitoring  framework  that  outlines  the  impact, 
outcomes,  outputs,  and  inputs  or  activities.  The  consultants  will  develop  baseline  road 
infrastructure  and  services  provision,  environmental  and  social  indicators  necessary  to 
effectively monitor project performance, and will collect baseline indicators as appropriate. The 
project  framework  will  be  developed  using  problem-tree  analysis  and  will  be  based  on  a 
participatory approach involving beneficiaries and stakeholders in project development, which 
will form the basis for the project performance management system (PPMS) and risk and 
sensitivity analysis.

village bus operator licensing system; adjust route structures and operations if necessary; and 
monitor operations to ensure that the objectives of the pilot project are met. (xi) Evaluate the 
results of the demonstration project. 
 
C.  Reporting 
16.  The consultants will submit the following reports under each part of the TA: (i) an 
inception report within 4 weeks from the start of the TA, which will finalize the approach, present 
a  detailed  work  plan  and  implementation  schedule  for  the  TA,  and  identify  any  need  for 
improvements in the subprojects for which feasibility study reports have been prepared; (ii) an 
interim report that presents a preliminary description of the investment project as a whole, 
including costing, assessment findings, and recommendations, to be submitted 12 weeks after 
the  start  of  the  TA,  together  with  an  interim  EIA  and  draft  summary  resettlement  plan; 
(iii) summary and full EIA reports within 20 weeks from the start of the TA; (iv) a social and 
poverty impact and indigenous people assessment report and a summary RP within 22 weeks 
from  the  start  of  the TA;  (v)  a  draft  final  report  (DFR)  covering  detailed  design  and  cost 
estimates, economic and financial analyses, and short best-practice or policy notes, to be 
submitted 24 weeks after the start of the TA; and (vi) a final report 2 weeks after the receipt of 
comments on the DFR from APCD, the IAs, and ADB, which should be issued no later than 
6 weeks after the submission of the DFR. 
 
17.  All reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. Three copies of each 
report (in English) will be submitted to ADB and four copies (in both Chinese and English) to 
APCD. The reports should address all aspects of the TOR to the level of detail appropriate for 
the given stage of the TA. The consultants will present key findings in workshops and the 
tripartite meetings, which will be organized after the submission and review of the inception 
report, interim report, and the draft and final versions of the final report.
